Eu tava ouvindo a trilha sonora da Shadowbringers e, do nada, bateu aquela sensação estranha de saudade — não de um lugar real, mas de um mundo inteiro que existe só dentro de um jogo. FFXIV faz isso comigo. Ele tem esse poder bizarro de acender memórias, emoções e momentos que eu nem sabia que estavam guardados.

A Realm Reborn foi legal. Sincero. Gentil até. Um começo que não tenta impressionar — só te convida a caminhar. E eu fui. E conforme fui andando, o jogo começou a se revelar: devagar, mas com propósito.
E quando percebi… já era tarde demais. Eu estava investido. Nos personagens. Nos diálogos. Nos pequenos detalhes que o jogo espalha como quem não quer nada, mas que ficam com você dias depois. Nas músicas que parecem falar com partes da gente que a gente não mostra pra ninguém.

Final Fantasy XIV tem algo que poucos jogos têm: coração.
Não o tipo óbvio, exagerado — mas aquele coração silencioso que pulsa por trás de cada cena, cada batalha, cada momento de paz entre uma missão e outra.

E a verdade é que eu poderia escrever um texto gigante — enorme mesmo — mas nenhum faria jus ao quão especial esse jogo é pra mim. Se eu fosse contar cada momento em que me senti cativado por ele, levaria um livro. E talvez ainda não fosse o suficiente.

No fim das contas, FFXIV é especial não porque entrega momentos épicos (embora entregue muitos), mas porque te faz lembrar deles. Ele fica com você.
Ele te acompanha.

E enquanto as músicas tocam —  fica impossível não lembrar do porquê esse jogo significa tanto pra mim.

Overall Grade: A — Strongly Recommended

Final Fantasy XIV has stood the test of time, evolving through expansions and updates to remain a cornerstone of the MMO genre. Even with mixed reactions to newer content, its storytelling, community, and worldbuilding continue to set the standard for MMORPGs.

Graphics — B+ 
Stylized visuals hold up well, with each expansion adding polish. Character designs and environments are charming, though the engine shows its age compared to newer MMOs.

Sound & Music — A+ 
Masayoshi Soken’s soundtrack is consistently breathtaking, with memorable themes and orchestral scores that elevate every expansion. Ambient soundscapes add depth to exploration and combat.

Combat & Gameplay — A- 
Combat is fluid and accessible, with a wide variety of jobs offering unique playstyles. Rotations can feel complex at higher levels, but the system rewards mastery. Some pacing issues exist in newer expansions, yet the core loop remains satisfying.

Story & Quests — A+ 
Narrative is FFXIV’s crown jewel. From A Realm Reborn through Endwalker, the storytelling has been praised as some of the best in the genre. Even with Dawntrail’s divisive reception, the game continues to deliver heartfelt character arcs and epic worldbuilding.

Open World & Exploration — B+ 
Hydaelyn and its expansions are vast and beautiful, with diverse regions to explore. Zone transitions and instancing can break immersion, and exploration would feel even stronger if load screens were minimized or eliminated entirely.

Performance & Quality of Life — B 
The game runs smoothly on modern systems, with regular patches improving stability. UI customization and accessibility options are solid, though some legacy systems feel clunky.

Business Model — C 
One major drawback is the subscription system. Once you’ve subbed for a month, you can no longer access the free trial, leaving you locked into monthly pay-to-play. For casual players, this feels restrictive and undermines accessibility.

Community & Longevity — A 
FFXIV’s community is famously welcoming, with strong social features like Free Companies, housing, and events. The game continues to evolve, with Square Enix promising further updates to keep it fresh.

Final Verdict Final Fantasy XIV is more than just a game—it’s a living world with stories, friendships, and adventures that endure. While the subscription model makes this game hard to play casually, the sheer quality of its narrative and community make it one of the most compelling MMORPGs available today.

Final Fantasy XIV is one of the few MMORPGs with a storyline I genuinely found myself invested in. Without spoiling anything, it’s a tale centered on unity, friendship, and perseverance in the face of hardship. In a gaming landscape overflowing with gacha systems, I found myself searching for something that truly captured the MMORPG experience of my youth—and FFXIV delivered. Its systems and tools felt familiar in the best way, offering that classic sense of adventure I’d been missing.

One of the game’s strongest aspects is its incredibly welcoming community. New players are marked with a small “sprout” icon, and this simple system goes a long way—veterans immediately recognize newcomers and often guide them through dungeons, mechanics, and early-game confusion. It creates a genuinely supportive environment that makes starting out feel exciting rather than overwhelming.

That’s not to say the game is without flaws. FFXIV certainly has its share of weaknesses, most notably the recent DDoS attacks that have been affecting the servers. It’s frustrating when downtime hits right as I get off work, but to the game’s credit, the outages have rarely lasted long enough to stop me from playing altogether.

Some players may also feel that the subscription required to play FFXIV is outdated in modern gaming. I can understand that perspective. But when you consider what FFXIV truly is, the model starts to make more sense. The original version of the game released in 2010, back when subscription-based online services—like Xbox Live Gold—were commonplace. While the subscription system it still uses is clearly a remnant of that era, I find it almost endearing. It feels like a fitting trait for what I consider one of the last bastions of old-school MMORPGs.

It's very easy to compare to World of Warcraft since WoW has dominated the MMO sphere since it's release in 2004... yet it does a lot of things differently.

First and foremost this IS a mainline Final Fantasy game through and through, that is a major strength as the story is well written, albeit in the case of XIV... it uses very verbose poetic archaic language and that takes some getting used to, but works well in the context of the world. It's a Final Fantasy game first, and an MMORPG second. Here is where I feel the comparison between it and World of Warcraft come into play the heaviest. Not to bash World of Warcraft or Blizzard, but... World of Warcraft, especially in modern times only cares about getting the player into end-game content, previous story elements and any sense of linearity of the storyline are cast aside, the player without a guide is often left clueless and wandering and that's to say nothing for the lack of in-game community.

Final Fantasy XIV offers the exact opposite of that. Playing though the mainline story is an experience and part of the leveling process. The leveling content actually matters to the overall story and it engages with the player. However people often refer to A Realm Reborn's story as a bit of a slog... that's not without reason, but once you've gone through later expansions it might not hurt to start a second character and go through ARR a second time to re-experience it and you might find that you missed a lot of elements you might have otherwise enjoyed with the newer context.

Mechanically the game is very solid, the community is engaged... though not as much as they used to be.
The only REAL caveat I'll say about this game is that you shouldn't buy it until you've gone through the totality of the Free Trial or there is something in the paid experience that you really really need to experience.

Final Fantasy XIV is "sunk cost fallacy - the game" and it really feels like the many longtime players telling you "it get's better later" are part of some pyramid scheme they're trying to push on you.
I got through the entirety of "A Realm Reborn" and a good chunk of the boring slog beyond that which you have to trudge through to get to Heavensward.

I'm sure the story get's better, I'm sure the cutscenes get more flashy and the voice acting improves, I've seen the videos talking about the expansion storylines. But the greatest story in the world is worth jack shit if it is delivered in this padded, uninspired way where 90% of the time all you do is run across the map doing dull delivery quests for NPCs. The story also relies heavily on you being invested in the Scions who I did not find to be particularly likable or interesting, but you're forced to join them anyway.

The pacing in this game is awful. It feels like it's intentionally padded to nickle and dime you for the monthly subscription. The writing has it moments but overall NPCs are way too wordy and verbose and it feels like the writers are just padding themselves on the back for how huge their vocabulary is and for all the clever puns they can come up with; it makes most NPCs feel very artificial.

Exploration is basically non-existent because there's nothing interesting to discover just venturing out on your own, the FATEs are a neat idea but most of the time you can't engage with them because they're outside of your level range.

Combat consists of pressing the same 3-4 buttons over and over again while dodging telegraphed attacks. The game is also trivially easy throughout the entire main story. There is absolutely no build variety within your chosen job whatsoever but atleast you can level all jobs on one character, that's pretty cool. New player experience sucks too, you can't take your time in dungeons and take in the vibes because you're gonna get rushed by other players who are just in here to level, the only solution to this is playing a tank since then you're the one dictating the pace.

Finally, the game feels very derivative. The different player races are mostly cripped from Final Fantasy XI with the interesting bits sanded off. The game is also filled to the brim with fanservice and references to the other FF games which was honestly the most entertaining part for me as a longtime FF-fangirl but it also leads to FFXIV feeling like it doesn't have much of an identity of it's own.

Even if the game does a complete 180° later and turns into a completly different, much better experience it is not worth the 100+ hour time investment to get there. I know MMOs are slower paced and deserve more of a grace period than other games but the time FFXIV spends drip feeding you boring slop is still unacceptable. In the time it takes to get through ARR you could play through multiple of the older FF games and have a much better time. I'm sure some people will say "well it's an MMO, what did you expect" but I don't think that's an excuse. I'm playing through Guild Wars 2 right now and it has none of these issues.

Don't fall for the weird, cultish hype FFXIV players have built around this game, it is not worth your time.

So I want to start slow and give my final thoughts about the game and how it feels going in and out.

The multiplayer feels non-existant at first, and getting people into the game feels like a chore if they all decide to start quitting back to back - Now the entire game is a glorified single player game, there's a lot of multiplayer content but I'd say it sounds more like endgame content once you're done with the entirity of the story. Lets say that you got a group of buddies, you're done with the game and you'd love to help them. There's a lot of multiplayer content mind you, but you first have to play a ton to actually get there... if not you can always buy skips. Skips prevent people from learning the game mind you.

The entire game is cosmetic - In endgame, after you finish through all of the game, the real content is fashion, and sure the game has stats but you pretty much farm for items just to look cool or to be caught up for the bigger and harder content. Your character's stats feel like it doesn't matter, same with the gear, materia and job. At the end of the day your character is cosmetic and the only thing that requires brain power is the telegraphed mechanics, the math in terms of crafting and specially the muscle memory on which player does their rotations the best. Also, forgot to mention drops on a lot of things are horrible, so expect to be farming like crazy. After completing the story, aside from just story it all feels empty, and the open world feels like playing section based areas like Borderlands. Don't get me wrong, a lot of the multiplayer content is super fun... deep dungeons and stuff like bozja and zadnor are both my jam, and stuff like the firmament is also addictive, there is a lot of really fun stuff to do in the game, but at the end of the day it's all about getting that sweet cosmetic.

f you're considering buying this game and you're coming from another MMO, there's one fatal flaw you should be aware of beforehand.
Unlike most other MMOs, Final Fantasy XIV locks its content not behind levels, but behind its story. So even if you level your character to max using dungeons, open-world content, PvP, or raids, you'll still be locked out of 90% of the content and game systems unless you've progressed through the story.
This story spans 978 quests, requiring you to play through all five expansions plus their patches. Even if you play daily, it would take around 200–300 hours to complete. The story itself isn’t bad—in fact, it’s great—but the gameplay loop is so mind-numbing that it can make you resent the narrative.
Here’s how it goes:
You watch a cutscene, do a fetch or “kill X amount” quest, then watch another cutscene. Repeat that cycle 10–15 times, and you finally get to do a dungeon (which you can run with NPCs). During all of this, you can just mash your head on the 1–2–3 keys and win 99% of the time.
The fun, challenging fights that force you to learn and adapt as a player are so rare and spaced out that you’ll forget they exist. If you're lucky, you’ll get two or three of those per expansion.
The phrase “It gets better later” should be the official motto of this game and its community:
- “When will my class (job) get more complex and fun?” — It gets better later.
- “When will the story speed up?” — It gets better later.
- “Do the fights ever get more engaging than this?” — It gets better later.
And they’re not wrong—it does get better. But only after 200–300 hours.
The best thing your friends can do while you invest those hours is walk you to quests or join you in low-level content that you’ll only touch once as you slog along to the next main quest.
This demand for such a massive time investment before “it gets better later” has created a divide between players. There are fewer and fewer of us at endgame. Unless Square Enix finds a way to fix this—besides selling story skips in the cash shop—I can’t recommend this game.

Since then, I’ve cleared Ultimates, raided extensively, and dedicated myself to PvP. From Season 1 through Season 10 I’ve played thousands of matches, climbing from Unranked to Crystal every season.

After all that time, one thing is clear: FFXIV’s PvP is toxic, repetitive, unrewarding, and abandoned by its own developers.

Crystalline Conflict was supposed to be the big PvP revival. In reality, it’s fast-food content: flashy at first, shallow once the novelty fades. One wipe snowballs into defeat, burst cooldowns matter more than teamwork, and every match feels the same. Worse, it’s not even part of daily roulettes, so most players never touch it. Spectator mode exists, but with no tournaments or competitive scene it’s wasted. And perhaps the biggest flaw of all: there are no duo queues. It is impossible to play with friends, even in casual matches, making the entire mode feel like a solitary grind instead of a team-based experience. What should have been the flagship mode is already irrelevant.

Ranked should have been the crown jewel of competition. Instead, it highlights everything broken with the system and the player base: matches are decided by button mashing rather than strategy, players chase scoreboard numbers instead of objectives, and fundamental mistakes—throwing overtime, chasing kills off point, wiping on the crystal—happen even in Diamond and Crystal. Toxicity is constant: AFKs, griefing, harassment, Quick Chat spam. Bots and scripters climb unchecked, and Square Enix does nothing. Balance swings wildly every patch, making class choice more important than skill. There is still no option for duo queues, which makes every match a gamble with strangers and strips away a huge layer of strategy. And the rewards? Titles, recolored mounts, recycled glamours. Ten seasons later, ranked PvP feels less like competition and more like a treadmill.

Rival Wings is dead: queues take hours or never pop at all. The mode is abandoned with no updates or incentives. Frontlines only survives because it’s tied to roulettes, but the gameplay itself is just chaotic zerging where RNG spawn timers decide the winner. Most matches feel like 20 minutes wasted. Both modes prove the same thing: if content isn’t tied to roulettes, it dies. If it is, people treat it as a chore.

New players get no onboarding, no tutorials, no guidance. Veterans end up carrying teammates who don’t even understand the basics. The fact that PvP still doesn’t have a proper tutorial system after ten seasons shows how little it matters to Square Enix.

And it’s not just PvP. Endgame as a whole has the same decline. Ultimates are brilliant but too rare to be true endgame pillars. Normal raids are formulaic dances recycled every tier. Expansions are padded with filler storylines, abandoned systems, and empty zones. Daily roulettes are the same grind with outdated dungeons. MSQ is bloated with filler dialogue and downtime. Progression is thinly stretched with time gates, recycled rewards, and little more than glamours, mounts, and housing items passed off as “content.” FFXIV looks spectacular, but it lacks lasting depth.

The community is marketed as the most welcoming MMO. At a casual level, maybe. But in competitive content, the mask slips. Players chase stats instead of wins, constructive criticism is rejected, and griefers, botters, and toxic players roam free with little to no punishment. These problems plague even high-ranked matches, where players should know better.

I’ve put in the hours: ten PvP seasons, Crystal every time, Ultimate clears, and thousands of matches. That commitment should feel rewarding. Instead, it feels wasted.

What FFXIV actually delivers today is simple: button mashing over strategy, stat padding over teamwork, bots and griefers over integrity, recycled raids and expansions over innovation, and rewards that disrespect the player’s time. Square Enix has had ten seasons and multiple expansions to prove they care about competitive content. They’ve failed every single time.

FFXIV is still a good story-driven MMO if all you want is cutscenes and cosmetics. But as a competitive game—PvP or PvE—it has no backbone, no prestige, and no future. In its current state, I cannot recommend it.

After completing the story, aside from just story it all feels empty, and the open world feels like playing section based areas like Borderlands.
